landing.title: Match your vote to South Africa
landing.subtitle: Answer 55 quick questions grounded in local policy debates. See which parties line up with your priorities for your community, province, and the country.
landing.privacy: Your answers stay on this device. No tracking, no accounts.

howItHelps.title: Why this matters now
howItHelps.intro: Coalitions, load-shedding, jobs, safety, housing. Compare parties on the issues that shape daily life in South Africa.

benefit1.title: Look past slogans
benefit1.text: See actual positions on service delivery, energy, crime, jobs, and land — not just campaign posters.

benefit2.title: Spot real options
benefit2.text: Find parties you may not follow, based on policy fit instead of social media reach.

benefit3.title: Read the field
benefit3.text: Get a ranked view of every party so you can see where they bunch together and where they split.

benefit4.title: Walk into the booth ready
benefit4.text: Decide with clarity before you queue. Save or share a link to your own answers.

about.title: About Elekti
about.methodologyText: Elekti is rooted in South African policy documents and public statements. We score across 12 issue areas that affect daily life and governance. The maths is deterministic and transparent.
about.howItWorksText: Fifty-five questions cover power, water, housing, jobs, safety, transport, coalitions, social policy, accountability, gender-based violence, informal settlements, and decolonisation of education. Each question links to an issue axis. You answer, we map your stance, and we compare it to each party's stated position.
about.scoringText: For every axis we calculate similarity between your answers and each party, weight by question importance, normalise by the questions you answered, then average across all axes. Scores are percentages; confidence reflects how clear the gap is between your top match and the rest.
about.transparencyText: All positions, weights, and calculations live in the repo. If something is wrong, send sources and we'll update. This tool is independent and does not promote any party.
about.dataSourcesText: We rely on manifestos, policy documents, voting records, budget speeches, and verified public statements. When positions change, we update.
about.privacyText: Your answers never leave your device. No accounts, no identifiers.
about.noTrackingText: We don't use cookies or pixels that follow you. We cannot see who you are or what you answered.
about.localOnlyText: Everything is saved in your browser. Clear your data and it's gone; we have nothing on our side.
about.sharingText: Sharing creates a URL that encodes your answers. Anyone with the link can view your result. Remove the link to keep it private again.
about.analyticsText: We use privacy-first, cookie-free analytics only to see if people are visiting. They do not record your answers.
about.partiesText: We list major parties contesting nationally and in key provinces this cycle. If we missed one, point us to their published policies.
about.disclaimerText: Use this as a starting point. Read manifestos, attend community meetings, and test our data. Politics shifts; so should your judgement.
about.viewDataText: All JSON files for questions, weights, and party positions are public. Inspect them yourself.

anc.desc: The African National Congress is South Africa's governing party, advocating for social democracy, transformation, and addressing inequality through state intervention.

da.desc: The Democratic Alliance promotes liberal democracy, free market economics, and non-racial politics with emphasis on good governance and job creation.

mk.desc: uMkhonto we Sizwe Party focuses on radical economic transformation, advocating for state-led development and addressing historical injustices.

eff.desc: The Economic Freedom Fighters is a far-left party advocating for radical economic transformation, nationalization, and land redistribution without compensation.

ifp.desc: The Inkatha Freedom Party primarily represents Zulu communities, promoting Zulu cultural values, federalism, and free market economics with social responsibility. While it has broader appeal, policy priorities centre on Zulu traditions and KwaZulu-Natal interests.

pa.desc: The Patriotic Alliance focuses on addressing immigration issues, promoting South African nationalism, and prioritising citizens' needs.

vfplus.name: Freedom Front Plus
vfplus.desc: Freedom Front Plus primarily represents Afrikaner communities and interests. The party opposes radical transformation and land expropriation, advocates for market-led economics and minimal state intervention, and defends conservative social values and traditional Afrikaner cultural preservation. It emphasises federalism and local self-determination for minority communities.

actionsa.desc: ActionSA is a centrist party focused on practical governance, anti-corruption, and economic growth through private sector engagement.

acdp.desc: The African Christian Democratic Party promotes Christian values, conservative social policies, and constitutional democracy.

ufc.desc: Unite for Change is a merger of RISE Mzansi, BOSA, and GOOD. It focuses on grassroots mobilisation and addressing local community concerns through progressive policies.

udm.desc: The United Democratic Movement is a social democratic party focused on clean governance, anti-corruption, and balanced economic policies that reward merit.

sacp.desc: The South African Communist Party advocates for socialism and workers' rights, and works toward a socialist society through state ownership of key industries.

atm.desc: The African Transformation Movement advocates for conservative social values, stricter discipline in schools, and stronger law and order policing.

aljama-ah.desc: Al Jama-ah is an Islamic democratic party promoting Muslim interests, social democracy, and conservative social values while working for all South Africans.

ncc.desc: The National Coloured Congress represents Coloured community interests and advocates for addressing issues affecting the Coloured population.

pac.desc: The Pan Africanist Congress of Azania is a Black nationalist party advocating for African socialism, Pan-Africanism, and land reform based on African ownership.

q1.text: The government should raise taxes on the wealthy to fund better health clinics, schools, and social grants for poor households.

q2.text: Government should pay down debt rather than spend on new programmes, even if it means cutting services.

q3.text: Government should give every adult a monthly cash grant, even if it costs more in taxes.

q4.text: Keep some coal and gas plants running for grid reliability, even if it delays emissions cuts.

q5.text: Healthcare should be free at clinics and hospitals for everyone.

q6.text: Higher education should be free for all students, even if it requires higher taxes.

q7.text: Schools should teach comprehensive sexuality education, including LGBTQ+ inclusion, even if some parents object.

q8.text: Government should actively support growing black-owned and worker-owned businesses through loans, tax breaks, and contracts.

q9.text: Municipalities should outsource maintenance to capable private firms under performance-based contracts to improve water and power uptime.

q10.text: Key public utilities (power, water, rail) should remain publicly owned and not be privatised.

q11.text: Allow private power generation with open grid access and wheeling, overseen by NERSA to keep tariffs fair—even if Eskom’s role shrinks.

q12.text: Water and sanitation should stay under government control, not be run by private companies.

q13.text: Government should seize land without paying full compensation to speed up land reform.

q14.text: Small farmers and communal land rights should get more government support than big commercial farms.

q15.text: Government should fund and protect community gardens, cooperative farms, and group farming schemes.

q16.text: Communities' traditional land claims should be legally recognised and protected, even if it overrides current titles.

q17.text: Strengthen workplace protections against gender-based violence and harassment and enforce them, even if compliance costs rise.

q18.text: Minimum wages should be increased significantly to reduce in-work poverty, even if some small businesses struggle.

q19.text: Making it easier for bosses to hire and fire workers will attract investment and create jobs.

q20.text: Workplace rights such as paid leave, sick leave, and severance pay should be strengthened and actively enforced across all sectors.

q21.text: Police need more funding and powers to tackle violent crime like house robberies, gender-based violence, and taxi violence—even if it means more police stops.

q22.text: People should be free to protest and speak out, even if it disrupts traffic, business, or services.

q23.text: Government and companies should not be allowed to spy on what people do online.

q24.text: Government should use law to stop disruptive protests and strikes, even if it limits people's right to resist.

q25.text: Local councils need professional managers and independent auditors to stop corruption and waste, even if it weakens political control.

q26.text: Courts and prosecutors must be independent and protected from political pressure, even if it slows justice.

q27.text: Corruption cases should be prosecuted fast and aggressively, even if it creates temporary chaos in government.

q28.text: Parties must work together in coalitions and compromise, even if they betray some of their supporters' expectations.

q29.text: National government should take over failing councils and fix them, even if it weakens local democracy.

q30.text: Cut corporate and personal tax rates to attract investment, even if it reduces short-term social spending.

q31.text: South Africa should set legal targets to cut pollution and close coal power stations.

q32.text: Government should invest more in solar, wind, and clean energy instead of coal.

q33.text: Environmental laws should stop new mines and coal projects when they damage nature.

q34.text: Government must protect LGBTQ+ people from discrimination at work and in shops.

q35.text: Government should force companies to give parents paid leave and protect mothers and women from discrimination at work.

q36.text: Prioritise SADC and AU regional value chains and logistics corridors to grow trade on the continent.

q37.text: Sign trade deals that align product standards and digitise customs, even if some industries must upgrade at cost.

q38.text: Government should use tariffs and local content rules to protect South African factories and jobs.

q39.text: South Africa should adopt stricter immigration and border enforcement policies, even if this strains relations with neighbouring countries.

q40.text: Government should crack down on employers hiring undocumented migrants, even if it hurts businesses that depend on them.

q41.text: Introduce merit-based appointments and fixed-term performance contracts across SOEs to drive rapid change, even if it disrupts existing arrangements.

q42.text: South Africa needs rapid, radical changes to the economy and job market, not slow reforms.

q43.text: Fix apartheid's legacy through slow, steady changes to institutions, not radical overhauls.

q44.text: Transport funding should prioritise improving minibus taxi routes, bus systems, and local trains over building new highways.

q45.text: Government should prioritise building affordable public housing in townships and informal settlements over private development projects.

q46.text: Cities should limit sprawling, car-dependent suburbs and instead support walkable, mixed-use townships with shops, schools, and clinics nearby—even if developers lose profits.

q47.text: Government departments must meet strict accessibility standards for people with disabilities, even if this impacts other services.

q48.text: Government should pump money into township and rural businesses to create jobs and economic growth.

q49.text: Employment Equity and BEE rules must stay as tools to fix racial inequality, even if companies complain about the costs.

q50.text: Government should invest in job training for historically disadvantaged people to get them into work.

q51.text: Government should fast-track land redistribution to smallholder and black farmers, even if it means less time for careful planning and training support.

q52.text: Government should dedicate significant budget and police capacity to prevent and prosecute gender-based violence and femicide, even if it diverts resources from other crime priorities.

q53.text: Government should provide water, electricity, and sanitation to informal settlements and upgrade them in place, rather than demolishing them for formal redevelopment.

q54.text: School curriculum should teach African history, indigenous languages, and local knowledge systems with equal weight to European curricula.

q55.text: State-owned enterprises should be radically restructured and given independent professional management, even if it disrupts current operations and employment.

disclaimer.title: Use this as a guide
disclaimer.educational: Elekti helps you compare parties. It does not replace your own research, and positions can shift as coalitions and policy debates move.
disclaimer.alpha: This site is under active development. We update data as parties publish and adjust their stances.
disclaimer.research: Read manifestos, budget speeches, council plans, and community briefings. If you spot issues in our data, send sources and we will correct them.
